"The full statement by Aristotle regarding the female as a "deformity but one that occurred in the course of nature" can be found in his book "Generation of Animals," Book V, Part 19:

"Here then is one mark of the female nature, that the female is more prone to conception and less apt for bodily movement than the male; the one because of its moisture, the other because of its coldness. For the female is more moist than the male, and moisture is the primary cause of conception. The female therefore is a kind of mutilated male, and the menstrual discharge is evidence of the defect. All females are therefore more or less afflicted with diseases of this nature, and are subject to these troubles as a result of their bodily conformation. And similarly with regard to other diseases: for the female is more cold and more subject to phlegm and other like affections than the male. So the female is a deformity, though one which occurs in the ordinary course of nature."

It's important to note that while this statement reflects Aristotle's views on the female body, they are not widely accepted or supported by modern scientific or philosophical understanding."

comment:
Just installed it on a Linux box. Very impressive. Re: 'What is true?'
After considering a cross-section of the reporting on this subject, 
I'll sum it up: "anthropomorphism run amok."

Obviously, the lure of the 'AI' mythology is irresistible to many computer geeks.
(No offense intended, I'm one of them. !;)
The fact is, this technology, i.e. the codebase itself, has nothing 
whatsoever to do with 'intelligence'. It is, at its core, clockwork,
no more 'intelligent' than Charles Babbage's Differencing Engine,
(or the IBM 360 I used to write my first computer program !;)  
 
That said, the goal of creating a 'language interpretation engine' is a 
highly appropriate extension of our electronic computing technology.
Our desire -- those of us who labor over massively complex (but essentially
inanimate bodies of code) -- to breathe life into our creation is perfectly 
understandable. My problem is this: those of us who understand the
fundamentally inanimate nature of our creations, should resist the temptation
to encourage laypersons -- those who have no concept of the intrinsically pedestrian
nature of 'program execution' -- to believe that our creations in any way 
resemble the workings of the human brain.

As I'm writing this, I'm listening to this exercise in mutual admiration by 
Mr.Fridman and Mr. Altman. To reiterate, I have the highest regard for Mr. Altman
and his colleagues and their creation. (I have a test in mind, which I strongly 
suspect will expose a weakness of  the GPT engine, albeit, I would be
delighted to be proved wrong!) That said, I'm eager to get in and explore
the potential of Large Language Models as a means of exploring and
expanding the usefulness of Large Language content. On the other hand, 
I see huge potential for systems like this to be exploited for financial and/or
political purposes by the worst malefactors of humankind.

author: @heine38

comment:
AI safety is not much about alignment or improvement of the AI, but more about creating fundamental worldwide rules about what we want an AI to control.
For example preventing the AI from controlling:
- Physcial control of weapons, rule/law enforcement, access control like locks or use of things.
- Control and selection of "facts" and the whole problem of the information rabbit hole (people getting "facts" from AI then write those facts, that the AI then use as learning and present as more probable fact .. repeat ad infinitum). We already have this problem with search engines etc algoritms that are already semi AI, but this will get much worse as AI gains more knowledge and improved.
- Control of data networks, access to data, power networks, and probably more (we ALWAYS want an off-switch that the AI can not prevent us from using). The probability of some version of Skynet seem very high.
- Physcial hard limit on how much computational power a single AI network may utilize (so humans mights control AI's rate of evolution, and also actually react in time).

However, even fundamental worldwide rules tend to fade over time. Freedom of speech used to be a human right (in western societies) but it is def. not anymore. UN's declaration of human rights are not really respected by any nation anymore (including western nations). And I also expect the halt of human genome manipulation will only last that long, slowly sneaking in over time.
BUT, even if rules about AI that we hopefully implement before it gets out of control, does fade over time; hopefully it will be delayed long enough that we will be able to better handle the problems - Because right now we are not prepared or suited to handle it >> we can't even agree on what is real and we don't understand how manipulated we are as humans by humans, much less AI assisted human, and much much less an AI in "full" control.

ChatGPT for sure has an enherited information rabbit hole problem, because of how it is made to act and learn from interaction with humans (directly or indirectly from people, or from people writing it's answers that it will read again in its next data learning pass). And I don't see a way to solve this as long as chatGPT is becomming a service along with search engines.

Last I would say, as a programmer I don't feel threatened by AI and so far I am with "if you think AI can replace you as a programmer, then you are in the wrong job" and that AI can help with some tedious task, and probably even make non-efficient (usability and performance) software. But it is unable to understand the complexity of expectations of stake holders and users, and also unable to see how software can be optimized from the perspective of user, usability, system design and more. BUT even though AI may be able to help us as programmers, I also completely agree that we should never teach an AI to program because of the real dangers of it reprogramming itself and replicating itself, this should be an aligment rule to put on any AI in my opinion.
